text:
I wanted to ask you about the
Socially Responsible Investment Index
that you designed.

It kind of speaks for
itself in terms of its name,

but tell me a
little bit about how

you got to that direction,
how you implemented it,
and its reception.
That in itself was one
of these things where
we learned a lot at that time,
and I think the JSE is still regarded
as a bit of a thought leader
amongst global exchanges for
the work that we did there.

So it was the time of the
Earth Summit in South Africa.

One of our stakeholders
came to me and said,

you know, Nicky, there's a lot
that's happening in the country

that organizations are
doing and claiming are good.

Whether that's how they
rehabilitate the land

if they're mining companies,
or whether that's their CSI

work, et cetera,
there's space here

to do something that highlights
the good that has been done

and incentivizes
companies that want

to do the right thing to see
where the bar is, so that they
know what they should be doing.

So to start to
frame the dialogue.

So it took a huge
amount of work

to do over years because the
dialogue starts from -- what is
socially responsible behavior?

Is it the philanthropic
work you do, or is that part
and is it enough?

Is it about how you behave on
your social license to operate?

What if you're a mining
company and you, by definition,
are destroying resources?

Does that mean you can't be
socially responsible when it's
legal to be a mining company?

But what if you're a
bank, and you lend money
to a mining company?
How do we think about that?

We had to go through all
of these discussions --

and really interesting,
intellectual discussions.
Then we discovered at the time

that it was essentially us and 
the London Stock Exchange

through FTSE, their index 
provider, who were really
the thought leaders.
Then Dow Jones came along.

And that started the
discussion in this country.

Essentially, you
start, and you sort of

say, OK, we're going
to set the bar here

initially just to figure out --
what's the data telling us?
What are people doing?

What you discover is that
the really big polluters,

because their legal licenses
require them to take

remedial action, et cetera,
have quite evolved understanding

of their responsibility
environmentally,

quite an evolved understanding
of their responsibility

to employees and the
communities around the mines --

perhaps less evolved
responsibility with regard

to the broader
communities, et cetera.
But entities typically at that time,

you're talking two decades
ago, like financial services

companies -- what
do I have to do here?
I've got my chairman's fund.
We put a bit inside for charity.

So actually, it's helping
people on a journey.

Today, I mean, it's
an amazing thing

to see the nature of the
discussion around ESG
and how mainstream it is.

To watch the discussions
around, OK, well, hold on.
Now we're about greenwashing.

We're trying to figure
out that when somebody says

they're doing something,
are they really doing --
what does it really mean?

I think one has got
to be a little bit --

it taught me at the
time not to be caught up
in the excitement of a theme,

but to actually look behind
the noise to the data
and what it's showing you --

to treat it as a journey
rather than a snapshot.

But that journey is
becoming an asset class,

and that's a very
interesting thing.
